metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: investigate and analyse theoretically and practically impulse in an isolated system for collisions between objects moving in a straight line: FŒît = mŒîv

impulse_definition.name: Impulse Definition
impulse_definition.correct: Impulse is the change in momentum of an object. It equals force multiplied by time, or equivalently, the change in momentum (Œîp = mŒîv).

impulse is force.error: Impulse is force √ó time, not just force.
impulse is force.fix: I = FŒît. Force alone doesn't tell you impulse; you need duration too.
impulse is force.action: A small force for a long time can give the same impulse as a large force for a short time.

impulse is momentum.error: Impulse is the CHANGE in momentum, not momentum itself.
impulse is momentum.fix: I = Œîp = p_final ‚àí p_initial. It's the difference, not the value.
impulse is momentum.action: Distinguish: p = mv (momentum), I = Œîp (change in momentum).

impulse is velocity change.error: Impulse is mass √ó velocity change, not just velocity change.
impulse is velocity change.fix: I = mŒîv. The mass matters too.
impulse is velocity change.action: Œîv is velocity change. Impulse = m √ó Œîv.

impulse is acceleration.error: Acceleration is rate of velocity change; impulse involves force and time.
impulse is acceleration.fix: a = Œîv/Œît, but I = FŒît = mŒîv. Different concepts.
impulse is acceleration.action: Impulse = FŒît. Acceleration = F/m. Don't confuse them.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what impulse represents.
persistent.action: Impulse = change in momentum = FŒît = mŒîv. Vector quantity. Units: N s or kg m/s.

impulse_units.name: Impulse Units
impulse_units.correct: Impulse has units of Newton-seconds (N s), which is equivalent to kg m/s (same as momentum units).

units are N.error: N is force. Impulse is N √ó s = N s.
units are N.fix: Impulse = Force √ó time, so units are N √ó s = N s.
units are N.action: Check dimensions: I = FŒît ‚Üí [N][s] = N s.

units are J.error: J (joules) is energy. Impulse has different units.
units are J.fix: Energy: J = N m. Impulse: N s. Different quantities.

units are m/s.error: m/s is velocity. Impulse includes mass.
units are m/s.fix: I = mŒîv, so units are kg √ó m/s = kg m/s = N s.
units are m/s.action: Impulse = kg m/s, velocity = m/s. Different.

N s and kg m/s are different.fix: N = kg m/s¬≤, so N s = kg m/s¬≤ √ó s = kg m/s.
N s and kg m/s are different.action: Both N s and kg m/s are correct for impulse.

persistent.action: Impulse units: N s = kg m/s. Same as momentum units (because I = Œîp).

impulse_vector.name: Impulse as a Vector
impulse_vector.formula: Direction of I = direction of F = direction of Œîp
impulse_vector.correct: Impulse is a vector quantity. Its direction is the same as the applied force and the same as the change in momentum.

impulse is scalar.error: Impulse is a vector; it has direction.
impulse is scalar.fix: I has the same direction as F and Œîp. Must specify direction.
impulse is scalar.action: If force is to the right, impulse is to the right.

direction opposite to force.fix: I = FŒît. Same direction as F.
direction opposite to force.action: Push right ‚Üí impulse right ‚Üí momentum increases rightward.

direction opposite to motion.error: Impulse direction equals force direction, which may be opposite OR same as motion.
direction opposite to motion.fix: If you push against motion, impulse opposes motion. If you push with motion, impulse is with motion.
direction opposite to motion.action: Braking: force backward, impulse backward. Accelerating: force forward, impulse forward.

always positive.error: Impulse can be positive or negative depending on direction.
always positive.fix: Choose sign convention. Impulse in negative direction = negative impulse.
always positive.action: If rightward is +, leftward impulse is negative.

persistent.gap: You're not treating impulse as a vector correctly.
persistent.action: Impulse is a vector. Direction = direction of force = direction of Œîp. Use sign convention.

impulse_momentum_theorem.name: Impulse-Momentum Theorem
impulse_momentum_theorem.correct: The impulse-momentum theorem states that impulse equals change in momentum: I = Œîp = m(v ‚àí u) = mv ‚àí mu.

I = p.error: Impulse equals CHANGE in momentum, not momentum.
I = p.fix: I = Œîp = p_f ‚àí p_i, not p itself.
I = p.action: Œîp means 'change in p'. I = p_final ‚àí p_initial.

I = mv.action: Impulse needs the change: I = m(v ‚àí u).

I = m(u ‚àí v).error: Order matters: it's v ‚àí u (final minus initial).
I = m(u ‚àí v).fix: Œîv = v ‚àí u. So I = m(v ‚àí u), not m(u ‚àí v).

mass must change.error: Usually mass is constant; velocity changes.
mass must change.fix: For constant mass: I = mŒîv = m(v ‚àí u).
mass must change.action: In collisions, mass typically stays constant. Velocity changes.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the impulse-momentum relationship.
persistent.action: I = Œîp = mŒîv = m(v ‚àí u) = mv ‚àí mu. Impulse EQUALS change in momentum.

force_time_relationship.name: Force-Time Relationship
force_time_relationship.formula: I = FŒît, so F = I/Œît = Œîp/Œît
force_time_relationship.correct: Impulse equals average force times time interval. For a given impulse, longer time means smaller force, shorter time means larger force.

F = IŒît.error: I = FŒît, so F = I/Œît (divide, not multiply).
F = IŒît.action: Check: if I = FŒît and you want F, divide I by Œît.

longer time means more force.error: For same impulse, longer time means LESS force.
longer time means more force.fix: F = I/Œît. Bigger Œît ‚Üí smaller F.
longer time means more force.action: This is why crumple zones work: more time = less force.

force doesn't depend on time.error: For a given impulse, force and time are inversely related.
force doesn't depend on time.fix: FŒît = constant (impulse). If Œît increases, F must decrease.
force doesn't depend on time.action: Same momentum change can happen with big F, small t OR small F, big t.

impulse depends only on force.error: Impulse depends on BOTH force AND time.
impulse depends only on force.fix: I = FŒît. Both F and Œît matter.
impulse depends only on force.action: 100 N for 2 s = 200 N for 1 s = same impulse (200 N s).

persistent.gap: You don't understand the force-time trade-off.
persistent.action: I = FŒît. For same I: increase Œît ‚Üí decrease F. This is key to safety design.

area_under_ft_graph.name: Area Under Force-Time Graph
area_under_ft_graph.correct: The area under a force-time graph equals the impulse. This works for any shape of graph (rectangle, triangle, trapezium, etc.).

gradient gives impulse.error: Gradient of F-t graph gives rate of force change. Area gives impulse.
gradient gives impulse.fix: Area = impulse. Gradient = dF/dt (how fast force changes).
gradient gives impulse.action: For impulse: calculate AREA, not gradient.

only works for rectangles.error: Area method works for ANY graph shape.
only works for rectangles.fix: Rectangle, triangle, trapezium‚Äîany shape. Just find the area.
only works for rectangles.action: Complex shapes: break into rectangles + triangles, or use trapezium formula.

area gives force.fix: Area under F-t graph = FŒît = impulse.
area gives force.action: Units check: N √ó s = N s = impulse units.

multiply axes for area.error: That would give N √ó s = N s, which IS impulse. But calculate area properly.
multiply axes for area.fix: Area = integral of F with respect to t. Use geometric formulas.
multiply axes for area.action: Rectangle: base √ó height. Triangle: ¬Ω √ó base √ó height.

persistent.gap: You don't know how to get impulse from a F-t graph.
persistent.action: Impulse = area under F-t graph. Use geometric area formulas for different shapes.

newtons_third_law_impulse.name: Newton's Third Law and Impulse
newtons_third_law_impulse.formula: I_on A by B = ‚àíI_on B by A
newtons_third_law_impulse.correct: In a collision, objects exert equal and opposite forces for the same time, so they experience equal and opposite impulses.

impulses are equal.error: Impulses are equal in MAGNITUDE but OPPOSITE in direction.
impulses are equal.action: If ball gains 10 N s right, bat loses 10 N s right (gains 10 N s left).

heavier object gets more impulse.error: Both objects experience equal magnitude impulse.
heavier object gets more impulse.action: But equal impulse on different masses ‚Üí different velocity changes.

only one object gets impulse.error: Both objects in a collision experience impulse.
only one object gets impulse.fix: Newton's 3rd: both exert forces on each other ‚Üí both get impulse.
only one object gets impulse.action: Ball hits bat: ball gets impulse, bat also gets impulse (opposite).

faster object gives more impulse.error: Both objects experience equal magnitude impulse regardless of speeds.
faster object gives more impulse.fix: The forces are equal and opposite. Same Œît ‚Üí same impulse magnitude.
faster object gives more impulse.action: Fast ball hitting slow bat: both get same magnitude impulse.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how impulse relates to Newton's third law.
persistent.action: In collisions: F_A = ‚àíF_B, same Œît ‚Üí I_A = ‚àíI_B. Equal magnitude, opposite direction.

change_in_velocity.name: Change in Velocity from Impulse
change_in_velocity.correct: The change in velocity equals impulse divided by mass. For the same impulse, a smaller mass has a larger velocity change.

Œîv = Im.error: Divide impulse by mass, don't multiply.
Œîv = Im.action: Check units: (N s)/(kg) = (kg m/s)/(kg) = m/s. Correct for velocity.

same impulse means same Œîv.fix: Œîv = I/m. Smaller m ‚Üí larger Œîv for same I.
same impulse means same Œîv.action: 10 N s on 1 kg: Œîv = 10 m/s. 10 N s on 2 kg: Œîv = 5 m/s.

heavier objects have larger Œîv.error: Heavier objects have SMALLER Œîv for same impulse.
heavier objects have larger Œîv.fix: Œîv = I/m. Larger m ‚Üí smaller Œîv.
heavier objects have larger Œîv.action: This is why heavier objects are harder to accelerate/decelerate.

mass doesn't affect velocity change.error: Mass is crucial in determining velocity change.
mass doesn't affect velocity change.fix: Œîv = I/m. Velocity change is inversely proportional to mass.
mass doesn't affect velocity change.action: Same impulse, different masses ‚Üí different velocity changes.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how mass affects velocity change from impulse.
persistent.action: Œîv = I/m. Same impulse on smaller mass ‚Üí bigger velocity change.

rebound_collisions.name: Rebound Collisions
rebound_collisions.formula: Œîv = v ‚àí (‚àíu) = v + u for reversal
rebound_collisions.correct: When an object rebounds (reverses direction), the change in velocity is the sum of the speeds, not the difference. This gives larger impulse.

Œîv = v ‚àí u always.error: Signs matter. If directions reverse, velocities have opposite signs.
Œîv = v ‚àí u always.fix: If u is positive (right) and v is negative (left): Œîv = v ‚àí u = (‚àív) ‚àí (+u) = ‚àí(v + u).
Œîv = v ‚àí u always.action: Ball at 5 m/s right rebounds at 4 m/s left: Œîv = (‚àí4) ‚àí (+5) = ‚àí9 m/s.

impulse is smaller for rebounds.error: Rebounds have LARGER impulse than stopping.
impulse is smaller for rebounds.fix: Stopping: Œîv = 0 ‚àí u = ‚àíu. Rebounding: Œîv = (‚àív) ‚àí u = ‚àí(v + u). Bigger.
impulse is smaller for rebounds.action: Rebounding ball: velocity must first stop, then reverse. More change.

direction doesn't matter.error: Direction is crucial for calculating Œîv correctly.
direction doesn't matter.fix: Use sign convention consistently. Reversal means sign change.
direction doesn't matter.action: Assign + to one direction. Opposite direction is ‚àí.

just subtract speeds.error: Subtract velocities with correct signs, not speeds.
just subtract speeds.fix: Œîv = v ‚àí u where v and u have correct signs for direction.
just subtract speeds.action: If both same direction: subtract magnitudes. If opposite: add magnitudes.

persistent.gap: You're not handling rebounds correctly in impulse calculations.
persistent.action: For rebounds: velocities have opposite signs. Œîv = v ‚àí u considers directions. Magnitude often larger than for stopping.

crumple_zones.name: Crumple Zones
crumple_zones.formula: Increase Œît ‚Üí decrease F (for same I)
crumple_zones.correct: Crumple zones increase collision time, which reduces the average force experienced. Same impulse (momentum change) occurs but over longer time.

crumple zones reduce impulse.error: Impulse is the same; only force is reduced.
crumple zones reduce impulse.fix: Same Œîp required to stop. Longer time ‚Üí smaller force. I = FŒît stays same.
crumple zones reduce impulse.action: Car must lose same momentum to stop. Crumple zone just spreads it over more time.

crumple zones make car bounce.error: Crumple zones absorb energy through deformation, not bouncing.
crumple zones make car bounce.fix: Crumpling = inelastic collision. Energy goes to deforming metal.
crumple zones make car bounce.action: Bouncing would mean elastic collision with higher forces.

harder materials are safer.error: Softer, deformable materials increase time and reduce force.
harder materials are safer.fix: Rigid = fast stop = high force. Deformable = slow stop = low force.
harder materials are safer.action: Crumple zones are designed to crumple, not stay rigid.

crumple zones prevent all injury.error: They reduce force but can't eliminate the impulse needed to stop.
crumple zones prevent all injury.fix: At very high speeds, even with crumple zones, forces may be too high.
crumple zones prevent all injury.action: Crumple zones are one part of a safety system.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how crumple zones reduce force.
persistent.action: Crumple zones increase Œît. Same I = FŒît means if Œît‚Üë, then F‚Üì. Less force on occupants.

airbags_seatbelts.name: Airbags and Seatbelts
airbags_seatbelts.correct: Airbags and seatbelts increase the time over which a person decelerates, reducing the average force on their body during a collision.

they reduce momentum change.error: Momentum change is determined by crash conditions, not safety devices.
they reduce momentum change.fix: Person must stop regardless. These devices just increase stopping time.
they reduce momentum change.action: Without seatbelt: stop in 0.01 s. With seatbelt: stop in 0.1 s. Same Œîp.

they make you stop faster.error: They make you stop SLOWER (over more time).
they make you stop faster.fix: Slower deceleration = more time = less force.
they make you stop faster.action: Goal: stretch out the stop, not shorten it.

airbags work by bouncing you back.error: Airbags deflate while decelerating you gradually.
airbags work by bouncing you back.fix: They compress slowly, increasing contact time with your body.
airbags work by bouncing you back.action: Bouncing would increase impulse (like a rebound). Airbags don't bounce.

seatbelts prevent all movement.error: Seatbelts allow some movement to increase stopping time.
seatbelts prevent all movement.fix: They stretch slightly and allow controlled forward movement.
seatbelts prevent all movement.action: A perfectly rigid seatbelt would cause very high forces.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how airbags and seatbelts reduce injury.
persistent.action: Same Œîp must occur to stop you. More time = less force. Airbags/seatbelts increase time.

impulse_calculations.name: Impulse Calculation Strategy
impulse_calculations.formula: Use I = mŒîv or I = FŒît
impulse_calculations.correct: Calculate impulse using whichever formula has known values: I = mŒîv when you know mass and velocity change, or I = FŒît when you know force and time.

always use I = FŒît.error: Use whichever formula has the known quantities.
always use I = FŒît.fix: Know m and Œîv? Use I = mŒîv. Know F and Œît? Use I = FŒît.
always use I = FŒît.action: Both formulas give the same impulse‚Äîchoose based on given information.

formulas give different answers.error: Both formulas are equivalent and give the same impulse.
formulas give different answers.fix: I = FŒît = mŒîv. They're equal by definition.
formulas give different answers.action: Use either; they're the same quantity expressed differently.

forget to use Œîv not v.error: Must use CHANGE in velocity, not final velocity.
forget to use Œîv not v.fix: Œîv = v ‚àí u. Include initial velocity.
forget to use Œîv not v.action: If object starts at rest, Œîv = v. If already moving, Œîv = v ‚àí u.

ignore direction in Œîv.error: Direction matters; Œîv is a vector quantity.
ignore direction in Œîv.fix: Use sign convention. Opposite directions have opposite signs.
ignore direction in Œîv.action: Rightward velocity = +, leftward = ‚àí. Calculate Œîv with correct signs.

persistent.gap: You're making errors in impulse calculations.
persistent.action: Use I = mŒîv (with Œîv = v ‚àí u, including signs) OR I = FŒît. Both give same result.

average_force.name: Average Force in Collisions
average_force.correct: The average force during a collision equals impulse divided by time. Real collision forces vary, but average force is useful for calculations.

F_avg = I √ó Œît.action: Check: if you multiply, units would be N s √ó s = N s¬≤, not N.

force is constant during collision.error: Real forces vary; we calculate average force.
force is constant during collision.fix: Actual force changes during collision. F_avg gives useful approximation.
force is constant during collision.action: F-t graph shows force variation. Average = impulse/time.

peak force equals average force.error: Peak force is usually higher than average force.
peak force equals average force.fix: If force varies, peak > average. For triangle graph: peak = 2 √ó average.
peak force equals average force.action: Area under graph = impulse. Average force = area/time.

shorter time means smaller force.error: Shorter time means LARGER average force (for same impulse).
shorter time means smaller force.fix: F = I/Œît. Smaller Œît ‚Üí larger F.
shorter time means smaller force.action: This is why quick stops are more dangerous.

persistent.gap: You don't understand average force in collisions.
persistent.action: F_avg = I/Œît = mŒîv/Œît. For same impulse: shorter time = higher force.

impulse_basics.title: Understanding Impulse
impulse_basics.instructions: Complete the statements about the fundamentals of impulse.

sentences.text: Impulse is defined as the {{d1}} in momentum of an object. It is represented by the symbol {{d2}} and is a {{d3}} quantity.
The units for impulse are {{d4}}, which is equivalent to {{d5}}. These are the same units as {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: N s can be rewritten as...

d6.tooltip: What quantity has the same units as impulse?

sentences.text: The direction of impulse is the same as the direction of the {{d7}} and the direction of the {{d8}}.

d7.tooltip: I = FŒît, so I is in the direction of...

d8.tooltip: I = Œîp, so I is in the direction of...

impulse_momentum.title: Impulse-Momentum Theorem
impulse_momentum.instructions: Complete the statements about the relationship between impulse and momentum.

sentences.text: The impulse-momentum theorem states that impulse equals {{d1}}. Mathematically: I = {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: The formula for impulse in terms of mass and velocity change.

sentences.text: For an object with constant mass, I = m(v ‚àí u), where v is the {{d3}} velocity and u is the {{d4}} velocity.

d3.tooltip: v represents velocity after the impulse.

d4.tooltip: u represents velocity before the impulse.

sentences.text: When a ball bounces off a wall, reversing direction, the change in velocity is {{d5}} than if it simply stopped. This means the impulse is {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Reversing direction involves more velocity change than stopping.

d6.tooltip: I = mŒîv, so larger Œîv means larger I.

force_time.title: Force-Time Relationship
force_time.instructions: Complete the statements about the relationship between force, time, and impulse.

sentences.text: Impulse can also be calculated as I = {{d1}}, where F is the average force and Œît is the {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: Œît represents the duration of the force.

sentences.text: For a given impulse, if the time increases, the average force {{d3}}. This is because F = {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: F and Œît are inversely related for constant I.

sentences.text: On a force-time graph, the {{d5}} under the curve represents the impulse. This works for {{d6}} shapes of graphs.

d6.tooltip: Does the method depend on graph shape?

safety.title: Safety Applications of Impulse
safety.instructions: Complete the statements about safety features that use impulse principles.

sentences.text: Crumple zones in cars work by {{d1}} the collision time. This {{d2}} the average force on occupants.

d1.tooltip: Crumple zones extend the collision duration.

d2.tooltip: More time means less force for same impulse.

sentences.text: Airbags and seatbelts also work by increasing the {{d3}} over which a person decelerates. The {{d4}} remains the same, but the force is reduced.

d4.tooltip: The momentum change is fixed by the crash.

sentences.text: Without safety features, a person in a crash stops in a very {{d5}} time, resulting in a very {{d6}} average force.

d5.tooltip: Rigid collisions have short contact times.

d6.tooltip: F = I/Œît. Small Œît means large F.

impulse_basics.title: Applying Impulse Concepts
impulse_basics.instructions: Apply your understanding of impulse fundamentals.

sentences.text: A 0.5 kg ball changes velocity from 10 m/s to the right to 6 m/s to the right. The impulse is I = mŒîv = 0.5 √ó (6 ‚àí 10) = {{d1}} N s. The direction is to the {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: Negative impulse means opposite to positive direction.

sentences.text: In a collision, object A exerts a force on object B, and by Newton's third law, object B exerts an {{d3}} force on object A. Since both forces act for the same time, the impulses are {{d4}}.

d4.correct: equal in magnitude but opposite in direction
d4.tooltip: Same force magnitude, same time, opposite directions.

sentences.text: A 2 kg object and a 0.5 kg object experience the same impulse of 10 N s. The 2 kg object has Œîv = {{d5}} m/s, while the 0.5 kg object has Œîv = {{d6}} m/s.

impulse_momentum.title: Applying Impulse-Momentum Theorem
impulse_momentum.instructions: Apply the impulse-momentum theorem to collision scenarios.

sentences.text: A 0.15 kg ball moving at 8 m/s right hits a wall and rebounds at 6 m/s left. Taking right as positive: Œîv = (‚àí6) ‚àí (+8) = {{d1}} m/s. Impulse = 0.15 √ó (‚àí14) = {{d2}} N s.
A golf club hits a 45 g ball, changing its velocity from 0 to 70 m/s in 0.5 ms. The impulse = {{d3}} N s. The average force = {{d4}} N.
If the same ball was hit with less force over a longer time, the impulse would be {{d5}} and the final velocity would be {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Same momentum change needed = same impulse.

sentences.text: A constant force of 50 N acts for 4 s. The impulse = area = {{d1}} N s. This is equivalent to {{d2}} kg m/s.

d2.tooltip: N s = kg m/s. Same number, different units.

sentences.text: A triangular force-time graph has peak force 100 N and duration 0.02 s. The impulse = ¬Ω √ó base √ó height = {{d3}} N s.
For the triangular graph above, the average force = impulse/time = {{d4}} N. This is {{d5}} the peak force.

safety.title: Analysing Safety Features
safety.instructions: Analyse how safety features reduce forces using impulse concepts.

sentences.text: A 70 kg person in a car crash decelerates from 15 m/s to 0. The impulse magnitude is {{d1}} N s regardless of safety features.
Without safety features, this occurs in 0.01 s, giving F = {{d2}} N. With airbag extending time to 0.1 s, F = {{d3}} N.
The airbag reduced the force by a factor of {{d4}}. This demonstrates that increasing collision time by a factor of 10 {{d5}} the force by a factor of 10.

d5.tooltip: F and Œît are inversely proportional.

sentences.text: The equation FŒît = mŒîv can be derived from Newton's second law by recognising that F = ma = m(Œîv/Œît), which rearranges to {{d1}}.

d1.tooltip: Multiply both sides of F = mŒîv/Œît by Œît.

sentences.text: When catching a ball, you instinctively move your hands {{d2}} with the ball. This {{d3}} the catching time and {{d4}} the force on your hands.

d2.tooltip: Moving with the ball extends contact time.

d4.tooltip: F = I/Œît. Larger Œît means smaller F.

sentences.text: A key insight is that impulse can be calculated two ways: from {{d5}} (using I = mŒîv) or from {{d6}} (using I = FŒît). Both give {{d7}} result.

d6.tooltip: I = FŒît uses force and time.

sentences.text: In a collision where both objects have equal mass, they exchange {{d1}} and both experience equal magnitude {{d2}} but opposite in direction.

d1.tooltip: Conservation of momentum: what one loses, other gains.

d2.tooltip: Equal and opposite forces for same time.

sentences.text: A common error is forgetting that {{d3}} is crucial in rebound problems. A ball hitting a wall at 5 m/s and rebounding at 5 m/s has Œîv = {{d4}} m/s, not 0 m/s.

d3.tooltip: Velocity is a vector; direction matters.

sentences.text: The maximum impulse occurs when an object completely {{d5}} direction because Œîv = v_final ‚àí v_initial involves {{d6}} the speeds when they're opposite.

force_time.title: Mastering Force-Time Analysis
force_time.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of force-time relationships.

sentences.text: A trapezium on a force-time graph has parallel sides of 80 N and 40 N with duration 0.5 s. Impulse = ¬Ω √ó (80 + 40) √ó 0.5 = {{d1}} N s.
If you know the impulse and want minimum force, you should maximise {{d2}}. If you want maximum force (like in striking sports), you should minimise {{d3}}.

d2.tooltip: F = I/Œît. Maximize Œît to minimize F.

sentences.text: Boxers are taught to 'roll with punches' to {{d4}} contact time, while martial artists strike with a stiff arm to {{d5}} contact time. Both strategies relate to F = I/Œît.

d4.tooltip: Rolling with punch extends time, reduces force.

d5.tooltip: Stiff arm = quick stop = high force on target.

safety.title: Mastering Safety Applications
safety.instructions: Demonstrate complete mastery of safety principles using impulse.

sentences.text: Modern car safety uses multiple systems: crumple zones deform the {{d1}}, seatbelts restrain the {{d2}}, and airbags cushion impact with the {{d3}}. All work by increasing time.

d1.tooltip: Crumple zones are in the car structure.

d2.tooltip: Seatbelts keep you connected to the decelerating car.

d3.tooltip: Airbags deploy where your head might hit.

sentences.text: A rigid car might look stronger, but it {{d4}} safety because the collision time is {{d5}}, resulting in {{d6}} forces on occupants.

d5.tooltip: Rigid materials don't extend collision time.

d6.tooltip: F = I/Œît. Smaller Œît means larger F.

sentences.text: Summary: For safety, we cannot change the {{d7}} (determined by crash conditions), but we can increase {{d8}} to reduce {{d9}}.
